newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada's Goodale plans revamping CWB legislation.
newsitem.headline: Canada's Goodale plans revamping CWB legislation.

text.p: Canadian Agriculture Minister Ralph Goodale said on Friday he is considering submitting legislative changes to the Canadian Wheat Board Act that would create a board of directors who would then have the authority to alter the agency's marketing mandate.

"Consideration is being given to place the governance of the Canadian Wheat Board in the hands of a board of directors, the majority of whom would be farmers," Goodale told reporters at a press briefing in Regina, Saskatchewan.
The CWB is currently run by three government appointed commissioners.
"The proposal that we are considering would provide for future mandate changes contingent upon the formal, considered advice of the Canadian Wheat Board board of directors," Goodale said.
An interim CWB board of directors could be in place by 1997, he added.
The 61-year-old state commodity trading agency is one of the world's oldest and largest such monopolies.
The CWB had a 21 percent share of world milling wheat markets and a 71 share of world durum wheat exports in marketing year 1994/95 (Aug/July).
"We are considering enabling legislation that would make it possible for the Canadian Wheat Board to make cash purchases of wheat and barley," Goodale said.

The CWB currently pools all wheat, durum, feed and malt barley deliveries into common accounts and pays one price for each commodity to all farmers. That has been a founding principle of the CWB since its inception July 5, 1935.
It was not immediately clear from the press briefing whether this would allow for a CWB spot market in grains.
Goodale will answer reporters' questions in a phone conference in about 90 minutes.

The proposed legislation would also allow the CWB to manage adjustment payments within a crop year, terminate pool accounts at any time and pay out farmers' returns rapidly, to issue negotiable producer certificates and use "modern risk management tools," Goodale said.
Future mandate or quality control changes implemented by the CWB could be determined by its directors and may go to a vote to the Prairies' 110,000 farmers.
"If the Canadian Wheat Board directors consider any proposed change significant, or fundamental, a producer vote would be a prerequisite before implementation," he added.
Barley marketing has been the focal point of an intensifying debate around western Canada's farms, agribusiness board rooms and provincial and federal cabinet tables in the past year.
A panel appointed by Goodale last December unanimously recommended removing feed barley from the CWB monopoly.

"On barley marketing, the Government of Canada is considering proceeding this winter with a formal poll among farmers to determine their precise marketing preferences with respect to barley," Goodale said.
Canada exports 30 percent of its feed barley.
